columns.text: In this problem, we need to solve for the bid price when certain parameters are changed.

For this, the depreciation will be solved by multiplying the initial investment by the given factors for a three-year Modified Accelerated Cash Recovery System method. The factors that will be used are:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Year 1}&=0.3333\\
\text{Year 2}&=0.4445\\
\text{Year 3}&=0.1481
\end{aligned}$$

For the Year 1 depreciation, we will have:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$5,100,000 \times 0.3333\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,699,830
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for Year 1 is $\$1,699,830$

For the Year 2 depreciation, we will have:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$5,100,000 \times 0.4445\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,266,950
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for Year 2 is $\$2,266,950$

For the Year 3 depreciation, we will have:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$5,100,000 \times 0.1481\\[15 pt]
&=\$755,310
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for Year 3 is $\$755,310$

It also states that the present net working capital is brought down to $\$25,000$ per year. This means that for the next $4$ years, the net working capital is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present net working capital}&=\$25,000 \times 4\\[15 pt]
&=\$100,000
\end{aligned}$$

The net working capital for the next $4$ years is $\$100,000$

Now we can solve for the operating cash flow using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=-\text{Initial investment}-\text{Initial net working capital}\\
&-\text{Present value of land}+\text{Operating cash flow} \times \text{Annuity factor}\\
&-\text{Present net working capital} \times \text{Annuity factor}\\
&+\dfrac{\text{After-tax salvage value of land and asset}+\text{Initial and present net working capital}}{(1+\text{Required return})^\text{time}}
\end{aligned}$$

Take note that we will set the net present value as zero in order to solve for the operating cash flow.

Simplify the values by adding the values that can be combined:

$$\begin{aligned}
0&=-\$6,650,000+(\text{Operating cash flow} \times 3.60478)\\
&-\$303,735+\$1,345,226.05\\[15 pt]
0&=-\$5,608,508.95+(\text{Operating cash flow} \times 3.60478)
\end{aligned}$$

Isolate the unknown then divide both sides by $3.60478$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=\dfrac{\$5,608,508.95}{3.60478}\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,555,853.33
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for this project is $\$1,555,853.33$
For this, the variable cost is how much it costs to produce a single stamp. In the problem, it states that each stamp costs $0.38$ cents which translates to $\$0.0038$

For the depreciation, we will use the value for Year 1. Substituting the values to the formula in Step 11, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\$1,555,853.33&=[(\text{Price}-\$0.0038) \times 100,000,000] \times (1-0.23)\\
&+0.23 \times \$1,699,830
\end{aligned}$$

Distribute the $100,000,000$ to the terms inside the parentheses then simplify the other values.

$$\begin{aligned}
\$1,555,853.33&=(100,000,000\times \text{Price}-\$380,000) \times (0.77)\\
&+\$390,960.90\\[15 pt]
\$1,164,892.43&=(100,000,000\times \text{Price}-\$380,000) \times (0.77)
\end{aligned}$$

Isolate the unknown then divide both sides by $100,000,000$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price}&=\dfrac{\$1,512,847.31+\$380,000}{100,000,000}\\[15 pt]
&=\$0.01892
\end{aligned}$$

The bid price should be $\$0.01892$ per stamp

To solve for the bid price for an asset that qualifies for $100$ percent bonus depreciation, we will use the formula in Step 11 and the depreciation that we will use is the same as the initial value. The cash flow will be $\$1,622,887.34$ which is the value we solved in the previous part of this problem.

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\$1,555,853.33&=[(\text{Price}-\$0.0038) \times 100,000,000] \times (1-0.23)\\
&+0.23 \times \$5,100,000
\end{aligned}$$

Simplify the values that can be combined

$$\begin{aligned}
\$1,555,853.33&=(\text{Price}\times 100,000,000 -\$380,000)\times0.77\\
&+\$1,173,000\\[15 pt]
\$382,853.33&=(\text{Price}\times 100,000,000 -\$380,000)\times0.77
\end{aligned}$$

Isolate the unknown then divide both sides by $100,000,000$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price}&=\dfrac{\$497,212.12+\$380,000}{100,000,000}\\[15 pt]
&=\$0.00877
\end{aligned}$$

The bid price in this situation is $\$0.00877$

As we can see from the two scenarios given that the bid price is lower since in the first scenario, the depreciation is accelerated which means that you get a higher compensation for the equipment which lowers the cost. The same is true with the second scenario where the asset qualifies for bonus depreciation.
